bioghist.p: Hans Ris (1914-2004) was born in Bern, Switzerland. He was a graduate of the University of Bern. In 1939 he was offered a teaching assistantship in Zoology at Columbia University, where he worked with the cytologist Franz Schrader and his wife, Sally Hughes-Schrader. In 1942 Ris became Instructor in Biology at Johns Hopkins University, and in 1944 he joined the lab of Alfred Mirsky at the Rockefeller Institute. In 1949 Ris joined the Zoology Department at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, where he established an electron microscope laboratory to study chromosome and nuclear structure. In 1969 he established the Madison High Voltage Electron Microscope Facility (HVEM). Ris was a founding member of the American Society for Cell Biology (ASCB) in 1960, and served as its first Treasurer and later served on its Council. Ris had an interest in Chinese society and culture, and beginning in 1985, he made several visits to Chinese laboratories; in 1990 he established a formal scientific exchange program between the ASCB and the Chinese Society for Cell Biology. Ris was a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and member of the National Academy of Sciences.
